text: Shirley gave a high pitched scream when she was upset.
speaker: Subject

text: I heard it often,
speaker: Subject

text: invariably directed at Janice's father or Elka,
speaker: Subject

text: his Hungarian mother who lived down the street and who tried to rule their lives.
speaker: Subject

text: Elka's the only reason Janice and Sharon shared a double bed.
speaker: Subject

text: When the twin beds Shirley had ordered arrived, Elka appeared and told the delivery men to take them back.
speaker: Subject

text: Sisters sleep together. That's the Hungarian way
speaker: Subject

text: and there was nothing Shirley could do about it.
speaker: Subject

text: As soon as Janice could form a sentence, she became the family translator.

text: Elka was intense.
speaker: Subject

text: One time I was at her house when the toilet clogged
speaker: Subject

text: and she rolled up her sleeve and stuck her arm in and unwedged the shit with her hand.
speaker: Subject

text: She'd been in the States like forty years, but never adapted. Her English was broken.
speaker: Subject

text: And when she rode in a car, she'd sit in the backseat white knuckling the door handle and saying slower, slower.
speaker: Subject

text: Outside it was so cold the snot in your nose froze.

text: Yeah.

text: We had no idea if the crystals on John's windshield were real or if we were hallucinating them.
speaker: Subject

text: John had just started computer school in Chicago.
speaker: Subject

text: He was all excited about it.
speaker: Subject

text: Said computers were the wave of the future.
speaker: Subject

text: That within our lifetimes, cash money was going to be obsolete and all money transactions would be done with computers.
speaker: Subject

text: They just introduced major credit cards.
speaker: Subject

text: And whenever you'd use your card, the clerk would have to make sure your card wasn't bad
speaker: Subject

text: by pulling out a booklet with thousands of bad credit card numbers listed in teeny type.
speaker: Subject

text: And everybody in line would shuffle impatiently while the clerk looked through the booklet to see if your card was listed there.
speaker: Subject

text: It took forever.
speaker: Subject

text: So we scoffed at John's foolishness.
speaker: Subject

text: But of course John's real foolishness was dropping out of computer school after six months
speaker: Subject

text: because he would have gotten in on the ground floor and he'd be rich.
speaker: Subject

text: I wonder what he looks like now. Is he pot bellied, balding, with a chain smoker's cough,
speaker: Subject

text: sitting in front of his home entertainment center, drinking beer after beer, feeling like a loser?
speaker: Subject

text: He was so handsome. A hothead and a loudmouth, to be sure. But his affection was uncomplicated. You could count on it.
speaker: Subject

text: Janice and I both loved him, though we never would have admitted it.
speaker: Subject

text: That hasn't changed for me.
speaker: Subject

text: When I love people, I hide it like a cat hides its illness.
speaker: Subject

text: As if my love were a dirty little secret.
speaker: Subject

text: I might love you for instance, and you'd never even know it.
speaker: Subject

text: I didn't think much about the future in those days. I wanted things to stay the way they were forever.
speaker: Subject

text: To be a college student living away from home,
speaker: Subject

text: check from my parents arriving at the beginning of each month.
speaker: Subject

text: I studied hard, aced my courses, got stoned nights and weekends. Nothing could be better than that.
speaker: Subject

text: My biggest fear for my future was that at some unimaginably distant point,
speaker: Subject

text: like when I was eighty maybe,
speaker: Subject

text: I'd turn into a person who no longer took ~LSD.
speaker: Subject

text: Some horrible old robot, all dried up and old and efficient.
speaker: Subject

text: What if I woke up into a twenty first century world without magic?
speaker: Subject

text: I long to look in the mirror and see that nineteen year old self standing behind me, sweaty and musky,

text: long strawberry hair parted down the middle ,

text: pupils dilated,

text: fingers ((gnawed)) bloody.

text: My sobriety, my reserve.
